``` ::: ::: ::: ## VAE ::: {#0e0c8a7e .cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} # sd vae is 3 down, 1 no-down, mid, conv, sampling, conv, mid, 3 up, 1 no-up ``` ::: ::: {#33b45679 .cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} class VAE(nn.Module): def __init__(self): super().__init__() self.enc = nn.Sequential(lin(ni, nh), lin(nh, nh)) self.mu,self.lv = lin(nh, nl, act=None),lin(nh, nl, act=None) self.dec = nn.Sequential(lin(nl, nh), lin(nh, nh), lin(nh, ni, act=None)) iw(self) def forward(self, x): x = self.enc(x) mu,lv = self.mu(x),self.lv(x) z = mu + (0.5*lv).exp()*torch.randn_like(lv) return self.dec(z),mu,lv ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

      2     def __init__(self):
      3         super().__init__()

NameError: name 'nn' is not defined
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {#a533f6b1 .cell execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} def kld_loss(inp, x): x_hat,mu,lv = inp return -0.5 * (1 + lv - mu.pow(2) - lv.exp()).mean() def bce_loss(inp, x): return F.binary_cross_entropy_with_logits(inp[0], x) def vae_loss(inp, x): return kld_loss(inp, x) + bce_loss(inp,x) ``` ::: ::: {#191c3bbc .cell execution_count=24} ``` {.python .cell-code} x = torch.linspace(-3,3,100) plt.figure(figsize=(4,3)) plt.plot(x, -0.5*(1+x-x.exp())); ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html}

NameError: name 'torch' is not defined
``` ::: ::: ::: **Question**: What would happen if the variance of the latents were very low? What if they were very high? **Bing**: If the variance of the latents were very low, then the encoder distribution would be very peaked and concentrated around the mean. This would make the latent space less diverse and expressive, and limit the ability of the decoder to reconstruct the data accurately. It would also make it harder to generate new data that are different from the training data. If the variance of the latents were very high, then the encoder distribution would be very spread out and diffuse. This would make the latent space more noisy and random, and reduce the correlation between the latent codes and the data. It would also make it easier to generate new data that are unrealistic or nonsensical. ::: {#3a449172 .cell execution_count=25} ``` {.python .cell-code} class FuncMetric(Mean): def __init__(self, fn, device=None): super().__init__(device=device) self.fn = fn def update(self, inp, targets): self.weighted_sum += self.fn(inp, targets) self.weights += 1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html}
